title.text: Sentiment Lexicon Creation using Continuous Latent Space and Neural Networks

abstractContent.text: This work presents a novel approach for automatic creation of sentiment word lists.

entities.text: automatic creation of sentiment word lists

abstractContent.text: In this approach, words are first mapped into a continuous latent space, which serves as input to a multilayer perceptron (MLP) trained using sentiment-annotated words.
When evaluated using manually annotated EmoLex corpus , our approach compares favourably with SentiWordNet 3.0, another automatically generated word list.

introductionContent.text: Many of the state of the art sentiment analysis systems uses input features based on sentiment word lists ( ).
While such lists maybe manually curated, automatic approaches are privileged if large lists need to be generated.
SentiWordNet 3.0 () is an example of such an automatically generated sentiment word list.
In this work, we present a novel approach for automatic generation of sentiment word lists.

entities.text: automatic generation of sentiment word lists

introductionContent.text: In this approach, words are mapped into a continuous latent space using two embedding methods Word2Vec ()() and GloVe ().
The mappings are given as input to a MLP trained using sentiment annotated words, which outputs a sentiment class or score for each word.
Results show that our method can create large sentiment lexicons with higher accuracy.
The method is based on a small annotated lexicon and large un-labeled corpora.
Hence, it could be easily applied to domain-specific contexts or underresourced languages.
